0.text: Holofernes and Nathaniel discuss Don Armado, with whom Nathaniel has been conversing. They mock his inferior intellect, criticizing his pronunciation and saying that they abhor 'such rackers of orthography' . Armado, Moth, and Costard enter; Armado tells the learned men that the King has asked him to prepare 'some delightful ostentation, or show, or pageant, or antick or firework'  to entertain the Princess and her party. He asks Holofernes and Nathaniel for their help in planning this entertainment, and Holofernes suggests that they present a show of the Nine Worthies. The men discuss who will play the roles of the Worthies, with Holofernes saying that he will play three of the roles himself. They then go off to plan their show.

2.text:
Holofernes and Nathaniel were discussing Don Quixote, with whom Nathaniel had recently conversed. They mocked his intellect, criticized his pronunciation, saying they detested 'that Orthography nonsenseness'.

Don Quixote, Mosca and Sancho Panza entered, and Don Quixote told the scholars that the king had asked him to prepare a 'charming performance, show, procession, acrobatics or fireworks' to entertain the princess and her guests.

He asked Holofernes and Nathaniel if they could help him plan the entertainment, and Holofernes suggested they present a show of nine worthies. 

They discussed who would play the role of the sage, with Holofernes saying he would play the triangle. They then left to plan the performance.

4.text:
Don Quixote and Sancho Panza entered, and Don Quixote told the scholars that the king requested him to prepare a 'captivating spectacle, entertainment, parade, acrobatics, or fireworks' to entertain the princess and her guests.

He asked Holoferns and Nathaniel if they could help him plan the entertainment, and Holoferns suggested presenting the performance of the Nine Wise Men.

They discussed who would play the wise men, and Holoferns said he would play the triangle.  After that, they left to plan the performance.

6.text:
Don Quixote and Sancho Panza entered the room, Don Quixote told the scholars that the king had asked him to prepare a 'pleasant show, entertainment, procession, flying men or fireworks display' to welcome the princess and her guests.

He asked for the help of Holophernes and Nastagio to plan the entertainment, Holophernes suggested performing 'The Nine Worthies'.

They discussed who would play the wise men, Holophernes said he would play three triangles of iron. Then they left to plan the show.

8.text:

He asked for the help of Hollenfensis and Nitro to plan the entertainment, and Hollenfensis suggested a performance of 'The Nine Worthies.' 

They discussed who would play the wise men, and Hollenfensis said he would play the iron triangle. They then left to plan the performance.

They discussed who would play the wise men, Hollenfens said he would play the Three Musketeers. Then, they left to plan the performance.

0.text: Jim and the Harling children feel the happiest and most content that spring just playing in the garden. They do not yet know that the summer will change everything. In the beginning of summer, some Italians come into town and set up a dancing pavilion in a vacant lot. They begin giving dancing lessons to children, and people start to gather and congregate around the lot. Now there is something for people to do and somewhere for them to socialize. Dancing becomes a city-wide craze, and every Saturday night there is a late-night dance. Jim goes all the time, as do many girls and boys from the country. At this point, Antonia, Lena, and Tiny become known as 'the hired girls' and are always at the dances too.

2.text:
James and Harrington's children felt the happiest and most satisfied while playing in the garden during spring, but they didn't know how summer would change everything.

At the beginning of summer, some Italians came to the small town and set up a dance hall on an empty square. The Italians began teaching dance lessons to the children, and people started gathering around the square. Now, people had something to do and a place for socializing. Dance became the town's latest craze, with parties held every Saturday night. James always attended, and every Saturday night, he would bring many village girls and boys.

At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were called 'hired girls' and always appeared at the dance.

Dancing became the latest trend in town, with dance parties held every Saturday night. James always attended, and every Saturday night, he would bring many girls and boys from the village.

At that time, Antonia, Lena, and Tina were known as 'hired girls,' and they always appeared at the dance parties.

0.text: Elizabeth reads through Darcy's letter with a mixture of emotions. When she first reads Darcy's explanation of his conduct with Bingley and Jane, she dismisses his explanation of his concern about Jane's indifference as false, and believes he acted solely because of her family. However, when she begins reading his explanation of the dealings with Wickham, she begins to read more clearly. She soon begins to realize that she had not known anything of Wickham before the night when he told her of he and Darcy, and she wonders why she didn't realize his impropriety at speaking of such things to a stranger. As she continues to reread and think, she realizes that she had been 'blind, partial, prejudiced, absurd,' and that she believes Darcy's version of what happened. She then rereads the section about Jane and Bingley, and sees that she cannot deny the justice of his description of Jane's seeming indifference after all. After two hours of wandering in the park she returns home to be told that both Fitzwilliam and Darcy had come to say their good-byes

2.text: When Elizabeth read Darcy's letter, her emotions were in turmoil. At first, when she read his explanation of himself and Jane, she thought his concern that she was indifferent to Jane was unfounded, and that his behavior was entirely due to her family. However, as she began to read his explanation of Wickham, she read on with increasing clarity. She soon realized that she had known nothing about Wickham until that night when he told her about his connection to Darcy, and she began to wonder why she had not noticed his inappropriateness in discussing these matters. As she continued to read and think, she realized that her previous views were 'blind, biased, partial, and absurd,' and she believed Darcy's version. Then, she re-read the parts about Jane and Bingley, and saw Darcy's seeming indifference to Jane as justice. After a two-hour walk, she returned home, only to be told that the Fitzwilliam and Darcy had already visited, and had taken their leave.

Two hours later, she returned home to find that Mr. Darcy and Colonel Fitzwilliam had already arrived.

0.text: Falstaff and Bardolph appear on a public road near Coventry, followed by a newly enlisted company of soldiers. Sir John orders Bardolph to replenish his supply of sack and to tell Peto to meet him at the town's end. He dislikes the idea of marching his men through the town in their rags and tatters. Abjectly impoverished, not one of them could pay him, as so many others had, for release from military service. In Falstaff's own words, 'No eye hath seen such scarecrows' . Prince Hal and Westmoreland meet him on the road and comment on the poor creatures whom Falstaff leads. The knight remains undisturbed and is philosophical in the face of this criticism. And, for that matter, the prince seems amused rather than indignant. All are to make haste, says Hal, for Percy is already in the field.

2.text:
Farleigh Bridge and Poldew appeared on the public road near Covington, accompanied by a batch of newly recruited soldiers. Farleigh Bridge ordered Poldew to refill his water bottle and told Peter to wait for him at the end of the town. Farleigh Bridge disliked the soldiers walking through the town in tattered clothes. He said, 'No one has ever seen such tattered people.' They were so impoverished that they could not serve in the military, like many others. Farleigh Bridge's words were, 'No one has ever seen such beggars.'

Prinsehaut and Westmorland met him on the road, criticizing the poor people he led. Farleigh Bridge remained calm, philosophically facing the criticism. In fact, Prinsehaut looked rather pleased, rather than angry. Hart said, 'Let's hurry along, Percy is already on the battlefield.'

0.text: Now that he has felt the pain of losing his son, Siddhartha has more sympathy with the needs and desires of ordinary people. He again decides to seek his son in the town, but stops when he thinks he hears a special message from the river. He remembers when he rebelled against his own father, and realizes that his father must have suffered the same pain as he, Siddhartha, suffers now. Sorrows repeat themselves. Still suffering, he returns to the hut and tells Vasudeva of his troubles. Vasudeva, in his silent attentiveness, seems to Siddhartha like a god. They both go and sit by the river bank. Siddhartha practices his technique of listening to the river and realizes the unity of all life amidst all its diverse elements. He realizes that in the unity is perfection. His pain disappears as his Self merges with the unity. From that moment on, Siddhartha no longer fights against his destiny. He accepts everything. Vasudeva, now that he has seen his friend attain enlightenment, announces that he is leaving. He is going to live in the woods and be in the unity of all things.

He recalled the scenes of opposing his father, and realized that his father must have also experienced the same pain as he was now. The pain was relived. He was still in pain, and returned to the hut, telling Vasudha about his worries. Vasudha listened silently, as if like a god to Siddhartha. They walked together to the riverbank and sat down. 0.text: Salisbury, Pembroke, and Lord Bigot come onstage. The battle is still raging. The dudes can't believe that King John's forces are still standing strong. That said, they thinks it's awesome that King John had to leave the battle with a doctor's note. Just then, in comes the French Count Melun, who's trying to hold his guts so they don't fall out of his body. Melun tells the English lords to abandon their rebellion and swear allegiance to King John once more, because if the French and the rebels defeat King John, Louis the Dauphin plans to have all his English allies beheaded. At first, Salisbury can't believe him. But then Melun explains that he is about to die, anyway, and he'll get a better reward in heaven by telling the truth now than by keeping mum. Anyway, he explains, his grandfather was English, so he has some sympathy for them. Salisbury definitely doesn't want to get his head lopped off, so he decides to believe Melun. Salisbury and the other English nobles leave the stage, taking Melun with them.

The Earl of Surrey, the Earl of Pembroke, and the Earl of Bigor appeared on the battlefield, with the battle still raging on. It seemed almost impossible that the King John's army could hold on. Despite this, they believed that the King John would leave the battlefield with a doctor's note. 

Just then, the Earl of Mere appeared from France, attempting to conceal his stomach, preventing his intestines from spilling out of his body. The Earl of Mere told the English nobles to abandon their rebellion and re-swear their loyalty to King John, as if the French and rebels defeated King John, Duke Louis intended to behead all Englishmen loyal to King John. 

The Earl of Surrey initially found it hard to believe him. However, the Earl of Mere explained that he was about to die, and that telling the truth would be a better way to gain a reward than keeping silent. Additionally, his grandfather was an Englishman, so he had some sympathy for them. The Earl of Surrey did not want to be beheaded, so he decided to believe the Earl of Mere. 

The Earl of Surrey and other English nobles left the battlefield, following the Earl of Mere.

The situation takes a serious turn because a similar incident occurred the year before: a young man had managed to seduce a student of the same college, maintaining that he was her cousin. 0.text: Mr. Micawber's Transactions Mr. Micawber, who thinks the move to Australia may be exactly what his family needs, wants to be sure that he arranges the finances between him and Miss Betsey professionally. Mrs. Micawber is very concerned that Mr. Micawber should repair her relationship with her family before they leave. Agnes, Traddles, David, and Miss Betsey meet to discuss the Micawbers' finances. Traddles has discovered that he can recover all of Miss Betsey's money as well as Mr. Wickfield's. Agnes says she will rent out the house and run a school in order to keep herself and her father financially secure. David, meanwhile, decides he will go abroad. Traddles reports that Uriah has left town with his mother, and no one knows what has become of him. Arrangements are made to provide for the Micawbers' debts and raise enough money to get them to Australia. Two days later, Miss Betsey takes David to a hospital and to a funeral. She tells him that her husband has died, and that he will not be a threat to her anymore

2.text: Mr. Michael Abbott believed that moving to Australia might be a lifeline for his family. He hoped to arrange his financial affairs on a professional level with Miss Bessie. Mr. Michael Abbott's wife was extremely worried and he had to reconcile with her family before they left. Agnes, Traddles, David and Miss Bessie gathered to discuss Mr. Michael Abbott's wife's financial affairs. Traddles found out that he could retrieve Miss Bessie's money and Mr. Wickfield's money. Agnes said she would rent out the house and open a school to ensure her own and her father's financial security. David decided to leave the country. Traddles reported that Uriah had taken his mother away and no one knew where he had gone to. To prepare for Mr. Michael Abbott's debts and to save enough money for them to go to Australia, two days later, Miss Bessie took David to the hospital and the mortuary. She told him that his husband had passed away and he would no longer pose a threat to her.

0.text: We begin with a prologue. An actor dressed in armor comes out on stage and welcomes us to ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been going at it on the Trojan battlefields for the last...get this...7 years. Since we're starting out 'in the middle' of all the action, the Prologue quickly catches us up to speed. You know, just in case we've never heard of a little old thing called the Trojan War. Here are the deets: the Greeks have sailed across the 'Athenian Bay' to 'ransack' Troy because a Trojan Prince named Paris stole Helen from the Greek King Menelaus and has been sleeping with her ever since. Simple as that. Next, the Prologue warns us that we might not like the play because nothing good ever really happens in times of 'war.' By the way, Shmooperinos, the Prologue says absolutely NOTHING about Troilus and Cressida, the two characters Shakespeare named this play after. What's up with that?

2.text: We start from the overture. Actors clad in armor step onto the stage, welcoming us into ancient Troy, where the Greeks and Trojans have been fighting on the battlefield for... seven years now. Because we start from the middle, the overture quickly takes us into the story. You know, just as we may have never heard of this thing called the Trojan War. Here are the details: the Greeks sailed across the Aegean Sea to reach Troy, intending to 'plunder' it because the Trojan prince Paris had stolen the Greek king Menelaus's Helen and had been sleeping with her ever since. It's a pretty brief summary. The overture then warns us that we may not enjoy this play, because in 'wartime,' nothing good will really happen. By the way, Shmooperinos, the overture doesn't even mention the two characters Shakespeare named in this play: Troilus and Cressida. So what's the problem here?

Although he told her that he and Justin had known each other for a long time in Ravensburg, she still refused to give up. Sir John went to find Justin's cousin, asking her to marry him, and told her that, although he had been rejected by Thomas before, the situation was now different. Justin's cousin rejected his proposal.

Justin's cousin met Wolfrick and told him that he was not Justin's only suitor. Wolfrick still refused to make a commitment, hastily leaving to find Justin and ask her if she would marry him, but she refused. Sir John returned home, saying that Clement (Justin's cousin's brother) would be back from Paris before Christmas.

Mrs. Weston disagrees, believing that Emma needs Harriet's companionship and that Emma's company will improve Harriet. She advises Knightley to keep his mouth shut, and the conversation ends with speculation about what will become of Emma. 0.text: Elizabeth, rambling in the park, often meets Darcy unexpectedly. On these occasions, he walks with her and asks odd questions about her likes and dislikes. Once she meets Fitzwilliam while she is strolling, and they speak of Darcy. Fitzwilliam tells her that recently Darcy has saved a friend from an unwise marriage, and he suspects this friend to be Bingley. Elizabeth is pained over hearing the news. She is furious with Darcy for ruining her sisters life. She later feigns a headache so she will not have to accompany the others to Rosings; angry with Darcy for his interference in Janes life, she does not want to see him.

0.text: According to Dr. Barlow's instructions, Dylan leads Alek to the machine rooms to check on the secret cargo. Dylan and Alek get into a tiff, but then they make up and Dylan explains a lot about the airship. Then they get into another tiff about which is better: machines or fabricated beasts. The two of them check the temperature of the eggs, grab the supplies Dylan left in the machine room earlier, and head to the sick bay. Dylan thanks Alek for saving him from frostbite--in a roundabout way, of course. On the way to sick bay, Dylan and Alek talk about how important Alek thinks he is, and Dylan reveals that his mother didn't want him to be a soldier. All this bickering and sharing of confidences means the two are well on their way to becoming friends.

0.text: Hamilton defends the treaty-making procedures outlined in the Constitution. He responds to the criticism that the Constitution wrongly mixes the legislative and executive branches of government by affording both a role in making and approving treaties. Hamilton argues that act of treaty-making does not fit neatly into the typical purview of either the executive or legislative branch. Therefore, affording a role to both is appropriate. Other critics claimed that the power to make treaties should be limited to the president. Hamilton responds that, unlike European monarchs, the president is only in office for a limited period of time. He may therefore be tempted to sign a treaty detrimental to the nation but beneficial to his private interests since he will eventually return to being a private citizen . It is therefore necessary that his power be held in check by the legislature. Others asserted that the Congress should have even greater authority over treaty making. However, Hamilton responds that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies to the process and weaken the American negotiating position.

2.text: Hamilton supports the constitutional treaty-making process. He responds to the criticism of the constitution combining legislative and executive powers by pointing out that the constitution has already assigned the treaty-making and ratification responsibilities to both houses. Hamilton believes that treaty-making is not a routine responsibility of either executive or legislative powers, and therefore, it is suitable to assign the responsibility to both houses. Other critics argue that the power to conclude treaties should only belong to the President. Hamilton counters that unlike European monarchs, the President is a term-limited official who may be tempted to sign treaties that are harmful to the country but beneficial to himself, as he will eventually return to his status as a private citizen. Therefore, his power must be checked by the legislative branch. Others argue that Congress should have more power to conclude treaties. However, Hamilton counters that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies, and would weaken the United States' negotiating position.

4.text: Hamilton supported the process of drafting the Constitution. In response to his criticism of the Constitution's allocation of legislative and executive powers, he pointed out that the Constitution had already assigned the responsibility of drafting and approving treaties to two branches. Hamilton believed that the drafting of treaties was not a daily responsibility of executive or legislative power, so it was suitable to assign the responsibility to two branches. Other critics argued that the power to end treaties should belong to the President. Hamilton countered that unlike European monarchs, the President is a limited-term official who might be tempted to sign treaties that are harmful to the nation but beneficial to himself because he will eventually return to his private citizen status. Therefore, his power must be constrained by the legislative branch. Some people also argued that Congress should have more power to sign treaties. However, Hamilton countered that this would introduce unnecessary delays and inefficiencies, and would also weaken the United States' position in negotiations.

0.text: After Leon had gone, Emma began a period of secret mourning. She drifted about aimlessly and was often melancholy. She saw Leon in her imagination as the hero of all her dreams and remembered their walks and conversations. She reproached herself for not having responded to his love, and he became the center of all her thoughts. In her misery, she began again the strange and unpredictable behavior that had marked her in Tostes. Her moods constantly changed, and she was often giddy and nervous. One day Rodolphe Boulanger, a handsome and wealthy landowner, brought one of his servants to be treated by Bovary. While there he saw Emma and was immediately attracted by her good looks and ladylike bearing. Boulanger was a suave bachelor, both coarse and shrewd. At once his thoughts turned to Emma's seduction, and he began to lay his plans.

0.text: Alek and his companions are at the Swiss border in their walker, but a German land frigate is waiting for them. Uh-oh... They decide the only way to get past it is to try to sneak by at night--because everyone thinks piloting a walker at night is too dangerous. The land frigate sends out searchlights at random intervals, which they have to sneak by. They try disguising the walker's noise by walking in a loud streambed. Pretty smart thinking. They run right into some German soldiers on foot, but the walker manages to plow through them. Alek speeds up, taking the walker into a run--at night.

2.text: Aleks and his friends were sitting on the Walker at the Swiss border, but a German landing ship was waiting for them ahead. Oh well... they decided that the only way was to try to sneak past it at night, as everyone thought it was too dangerous to drive the Walker at night. The landing ship would occasionally fire spotlights, and they had to avoid them. They tried to mask the noise of the Walker by walking along a noisy river. What a clever idea. 0.text: Over two years have passed. Jude and Sue lead a wandering life, stopping wherever Jude can find work as a mason. However, he refuses to do any church work. At the little town of Kennetbridge, Arabella and Anny arrive one day. Arabella is now widowed and is in mourning and has come to Kennetbridge to see the laying of a foundation stone of a new chapel. She claims that she has now turned to religion for consolation. She suddenly spots Sue and Little Father Time selling cakes and gingerbread at a stall at the fair. She questions Sue and learns that Jude was very ill that winter, and they have therefore tried their hand at baking in an attempt to earn a living. Sue now has two children of her own and is expecting a third. The cakes Jude makes are shaped like Christminster colleges, with towers and pinnacles and traceried windows, indicating that Jude still has a passion for Christminster.

2.text: They had not lived like vagrants for two years, and as long as Zhude could find a place to work as a stonemason, they would stop for a while. However, he refused to get involved in any church work. Arbella and Anne came to Kennington Bridge one day, and Arbella had become a widow, deeply sorrowful and seeking solace, so she came to Kennington Bridge to visit the laying of the foundation stone of the new church. She claimed that she had now turned to religion to seek solace. Suddenly, she saw Su and young Zhude selling cakes and gingerbread on the street stall. She asked Su, and upon learning that Zhude was extremely uncomfortable in the winter, they tried to make a living through baking. Now Su had two children and was pregnant with her third. Zhude's cakes mimicked the style of Kristiansand Cathedral, with towers, spires, and colored windows, indicating that Zhude still had a deep passion for Kristiansand.

0.text: The mayoral election comes up for Zenith, and the left-wing lawyer Seneca Doane is running. That means that Babbitt and his pro-business brotherhood need to fire up their election machine and get anyone other than Doane into office. They promote a candidate named Lucas Prout and Babbitt goes around giving speeches in support of Prout. Ultimately, Babbitt's efforts are able to get Lucas Prout elected mayor. The business community survives another big scare from organized labor. Now that he has an established reputation as a speechmaker, Babbitt is invited to all sorts of functions to give speeches about business and about the glory of Zenith. One of the main points in his speeches is that state universities should fire all professors who preach liberal or socialist views. As his star continues to rise in Zenith's social circles, Babbitt wonders how he ever could have doubted the joys of being a solid citizen.

Ultimately, Babette's efforts ensured Lucas Pruitt's election as mayor, thus avoiding another major crisis triggered by the union. Charles de Val arrived later, and they chatted for a while. Once the servant left, de Val told his uncle that he wanted to cut ties with the family and France.

Despite Maximus appearing calm and polite on the surface, he did not actually like his nephew. On the other hand, de Val hated his uncle, and every time he mentioned the name 'Ivlatas', he was filled with fear and hatred.

They parted ways, and when Maximus asked de Val about the relationship between Dr. Demivier and Lucy, a faint smile appeared.

The next morning, people found that Maximus was already dead - he had been killed by the Jacobins.

2.text: The narrator of the story brings the reader to the home of Reverend Adam Irwine in Hayslope, a district in Broxton, where he resides with his mother, Mrs. Irwine, a woman of high social standing. Mr. Irwine has chosen to care for his mother and two unmarried sisters, rather than establish a family of his own, and thus becomes a lifelong bachelor. One of his sisters has been bedridden for a long time. Joshua Rann, the shoemaker and parish clerk of Broxton, comes to visit Mr. Irwine, complaining about the new sect and Dinah. Mr. Rann particularly complains about William Maskery, a member of the new sect, who has previously slandered both Mr. Irwine and himself. Mr. Irwine contemptuously mocks Mr. Rann's complaints, telling him not to interfere in Maskery's affairs. After Mr. Rann leaves, Lieutenant Arthur Donnithorne comes to visit Mr. Irwine, inviting him to join him for a ride. Lieutenant Donnithorne is the grandson and heir of the local gentleman, Mr. Donnithorne, and is known as the 'young gentleman' in the village. He is a handsome man who is recovering at his family's estate after being injured during his military service. Mr. Rann tells Mr. Irwine and Lieutenant Donnithorne that Thias Bede has passed away, who is Adam's father.

4.text: The narrator takes the reader to the Haslup district of Brookline, to the home of Reverend Adam Irwin, where he lives with his mother, Mrs. Irwin, a woman of high social standing. Reverend Irwin has decided to care for his mother and two spinster sisters, rather than establishing a family of his own, thus dedicating himself to a life of celibacy. One of his sisters has been bedridden for a long time. The shoemaker and church clerk, Joshua Larn, comes to Reverend Irwin's home, complaining about the New Lights and Dina. Mr. Larn is especially angry at William Muskrat, a member of the New Lights, who had previously slandered Reverend Irwin and Mr. Larn himself. Reverend Irwin contemptuously dismisses Mr. Larn's complaints, telling him not to interfere with Muskrat's affairs. After Mr. Larn leaves, Captain Arthur Dennison comes to Reverend Irwin's home, inviting him to join him for a ride. Captain Dennison is the grandson and heir of the local gentleman, Mr. Dennison, and is known in the village as 'the young gentleman.' 0.text: As this scene opens, Cyrano is in a state of frenzied exhilaration because Roxane has acknowledged his existence. He wishes to prove his worth to her by showing his valor. Two gentlemen, Cuigy and Brissaille, enter with the drunken Ligniere, who declares that a hundred men are waiting to attack him. Cyrano offers to offer him protection, by escorting him with a troop of officers. He declares, however, that he will find the attackers alone and unaided. As they prepare to leave, several others join the group, wishing to witness what happens at the Porte de Nesle. When they depart, Cyrano is proudly at the head of the group. He pauses to say that it was necessary to send one hundred men to kill Ligniere because everyone knows he is a friend of his, implying that everyone fears Cyrano.

2.text: As the scene begins, Sir Lancelot is in a state of fervent excitement, for Guinevere has acknowledged his presence. He hopes to prove his worth to her by demonstrating his bravery. Sir Lancelot offers to protect him, leading a group of officials to escort him. However, he declares that he will go alone to find the attackers. He stops and says that a hundred men must be sent to kill Gawain, because everyone knows that he is his friend, which means that everyone is afraid of Sir Lancelot.

0.text: The mender of roads who spotted the man under the Marquis St. Evremonde's carriage accompanies Defarge to the wine-shop. In the garret where Doctor Alexandre Manette stayed, Defarge and Jacques One, Two, and Three listen to the road-mender describe what happened to Gaspard, the man who killed the Marquis. Gaspard, who murdered the Marquis for running down his child, went into hiding for nearly a year after the killing. The French authorities recently captured, jailed, and hanged him, and left his corpse dangling by the village fountain, with his shadow poisoning the atmosphere of the town. Monsieur and Madame Defarge later take the road-mender to Versailles, where the splendor of the court dazzles him. Caught up in the emotion of the experience, the road-mender cheers the King, Queen, and other nobles. The Defarges commend his behavior, feeling that it will fuel the courtiers' arrogance and ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Additionally, the Defarges believe that the sight of such luxury and finery will supply the road-mender with a focus for his hatred and violence in the future.

2.text:
A road repair worker stumbled upon a man beneath the carriage of Baron de Marais Saint Evremond, and the man subsequently followed D'Artagnan to a tavern. D'Artagnan and Jacques I, II, and III listened as the road repair worker recounted the story of Gaspar, who had been involved in the assassination of Baron de Marais Saint Evremond. Gaspar had killed the Baron because he had been involved in an accident that had injured the Baron's child; after the murder, he hid for nearly a year. Recently, the French authorities had apprehended him, imprisoned him, hanged him, and hung his body beside a fountain in the village, allowing his shadow to cast a dark atmosphere over the entire village.

D'Artagnan and his wife later brought the road repair worker to Versailles, where the road repair worker was awestruck by the grandeur of the palace. Infected by this experience, the road repair worker loudly praised the king, queen, and other nobles. D'Artagnan and his wife approved of his actions, believing that it would provoke the haughtiness of the court officials and their ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Additionally, D'Artagnan and his wife thought that seeing such opulence would make the road repair worker a target for hatred and violence in the future.

4.text:
In the vicinity of Barondes de Mairais Saint-Evremond, a roadworker discovered a man hiding beneath a carriage. The man later accompanied D'Artagnan to a tavern, where D'Artagnan and three musketeers  Athos, Porthos, and Aramis  listened as the roadworker recounted the story of Gaspar. Gaspar had been involved in the assassination of Barondes de Mairais Saint-Evremond, as he had been responsible for the injury of the latter's child in an accident; he had then gone into hiding for almost a year following the assassination. Recently, the French authorities had apprehended him, imprisoned him, and executed him by hanging his body near a well in the village, casting a dark shadow over the entire village.

D'Artagnan and his wife later brought the roadworker to Versailles, where the roadworker was awestruck by the grandeur of the palace. This experience left a profound impact on the roadworker, who loudly praised the king, queen, and other nobles. D'Artagnan and his wife approved of the roadworker's behavior, believing it would infuriate the pride of the court officials and their ignorance of the revolutionary movement. Furthermore, D'Artagnan and his wife thought that witnessing such opulence would make the roadworker a target for future hatred and violence.

6.text:
In the vicinity of Balondes de Melayes Saint-Evremond, a road worker stumbled upon a man hiding beneath a carriage. 0.text: Fire Rises The French countryside lies ruined and desolate. An unidentified man, weary from travel, meets the mender of roads. They address each other as 'Jacques' to indicate their status as revolutionaries. The mender of roads directs the man to the chateau of the murdered Marquis. Later that night, the man sets the castle on fire. A rider from the chateau urges the village soldiers to help put out the fire and salvage the valuables there, but they refuse, and the villagers go inside their homes and put 'candles in every dull little pane of glass. The peasants nearly kill Gabelle, the local tax collector, but he escapes to the roof of his house, where he watches the chateau burn. The narrator reports that scenes such as this are occurring all over France

2.text: In the French countryside, a devastating and desolate landscape was left in the wake of a massive fire. A mysterious man, exhausted from his journey, encountered a road worker. They referred to each other as 'Jacques' to signify their status as fellow revolutionaries. The road worker led the man to the castle of the murdered Marquis de Massiac. On the night, the man set the castle ablaze. The castle's groom called out to the village soldiers to put out the flames and rescue the valuable items inside, but the soldiers refused and instead returned home to light candles in every window. Peasants were on the verge of lynching the local tax collector, Barthlmy, but he fled to the roof, witnessing the castle burn. The narrator reports that such scenes were unfolding across France.

0.text: Joe Welling lives with his mother in Winesburg. Though a man of small stature, he is like a 'living volcano'. He is subject to fits of ideas, whereupon he becomes uncontrollable, words spout from his mouth in torrents, and the person who is his victim then has no escape. He works as an agent for the standard Oil Company, but he can accost anyone on the road and rapidly begin shooting words at him. He is a terror for the Winesburg citizens. But when Joe organizes the baseball club, he is considered a savior, as he can channel his ideas and excitement into the players and make them win. Joe falls in love with Sarah king a lean, sad-looking woman. Her brother Tom is considered dangerous, and so is his father Edward, the people of Winesburg can't help laughing at the odd pair but are afraid for Joe. George Willard reports his meeting with the two Kings. Apparently, Joe has managed to sweep away the two, by his torrent of words and ideas. His ideas have managed to perplex the two men and have given them no chance to counter attack Joe.

2.text: Joe Wilner lived with his mother in Wienersburg. Despite his short stature, he was like a 'live volcano.' Joe fell in love with Sara Gold, who was tall and thin with a sorrowful face. Her brother Tom was considered a threat, and her father Edward was the same. 0.text: During their layover in New York, Paul wants to see the Aquitania, declaring that he 'Always wanted to go to Europe'. As they stare at the line, Paul becomes so tense and agitated that they have to leave. In Maine, George and Paul spend their time relaxing and sitting at the edge of a wharf. For the week before their families arrive, the men indulge themselves by sleeping late, chewing tobacco, playing poker late into the night, and not bathing every day. They view the vacation as a chance to get 'a good rest. and start over again'. Over the course of the week, Paul becomes increasingly relaxed and cheerful, whereas George becomes increasingly weary and overwrought. When his family arrives, he is agitated again and reminded of his troublesome sense of obligation, though he is able to enjoy spending time with Ted and feels somewhat rejuvenated

0.text: In the opening chapter, the period in which the novel is set is described. The story begins about fifteen years before the French Revolution. It is a time when many people think they live in the best of times, while others condemn it as the worst of times. The kings of England and France are both mediocre rulers, and they believe in their divine rights. People are put to death for the slightest of crimes. The condition in France is very bad, for there is a total disregard for the common people by the aristocracy; injustice, cruelty, and oppression are rampant. The aristocracy is unaware that the masses are preparing for the revolution by turning timber into guillotines and farm carts into tumbrels to convey people to the guillotine. In England, too, lawlessness and poverty prevail. Even the colonies in America are up in arms against their English rulers, and the attempts of the American colonies to obtain freedom are not taken seriously.

0.text: Jane's students become more familiar and endeared to her, and Jane becomes quite popular among them. At night, though, she has troubling nightmares that involve Rochester. Jane continues to pay attention to the relationship between St. John and Rosamond, who often visits the school when she knows St. John will be there. Rosamond asks Jane to draw her portrait, and as she is working on it one day, St. John pays her a visit. He gives her a new book of poetry and looks at the drawing. She offers to draw him a duplicate, and then boldly declares that he ought to marry Rosamond. St. John admits that he loves her and is tempted by her beauty, but he explains that he refuses to allow worldly affection to interfere with his holy duties. The flirtatious, silly, and shallow Rosamond would make a terrible wife for a missionary. Suddenly, St. John notices something on the edge of Jane's paper and tears off a tiny piece--Jane is not certain why. With a peculiar look on his face, he hurries from the room

0.text: The group treads barefoot through a stream in order to hide its tracks. They pass a pond, and Hawkeye tells the group it is filled with corpses of slain French soldiers. As they near the besieged Fort William Henry, they encounter a French sentinel. Heyward talks to him in French, distracting him while Chingachgook sneaks up to the sentinel, kills him, and scalps him. Firing breaks out between English troops protecting the fort and French forces, and the crossfire puts the party in danger. Thick fog conceals them, however, and they attempt to find their way to the fort through the sounds of battle. The French forces pursue them, but they arrive at the fort safely. As they enter the fort, Colonel Munro weeps and embraces his daughters

0.text: Jane is feeling better, and after dinner she comes into the drawing-room for a few hours where she and Bingley spend much time talking over by the fire. Miss Bingley notices that Darcy does not watch her walk about the room, so asks Elizabeth also to walk, and sees that Darcy admires her. Elizabeth has a discussion with Darcy about pride and how he cannot 'forget the follies and vices of others so soon as ought, nor their offenses against , and she states that his defect is 'a propensity to hate everybody,' while he states that hers 'is willfully to misunderstand them

Jane Austen gradually recovered, and she returned to the drawing room a few hours after dinner, sitting by the fireplace and chatting with Mr. Bingley.

Mr. Darcy inquired of Mr. Bingley whether he had truly considered hosting a ball at Netherfield, to which Mr. Bingley replied that he had.

Mr. Darcy noticed that Elizabeth was not looking at him, so he invited her to join him, and when he saw that she was gazing at him, he began to converse with her.

Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy engaged in a discussion of pride, he saying that he found it difficult to easily forget the mistakes and transgressions of others, while Elizabeth said that his mistake was 'disliking everyone,' and Mr. Darcy said that her mistake was 'willfully misinterpreting others.'

0.text: The men run off to fight, and Roxane collapses over Christian's body. Cyrano leans down and whispers into Christian's ear that he told Roxane the secret, and that she chose Christian. The battle breaks out all around them and Christian closes his eyes, dead. Next to Christian's heart, Roxane finds the farewell letter that Cyrano wrote for Christian to give her. She faints with grief, and Cyrano sends Ragueneau and de Guiche to take her away and protect her. Carbon emerges from the fighting, twice wounded. But the army has returned, and the men will win if they can hold out only a little longer. Cyrano tells Carbon not to worry. Now, he says, he has two deaths to avenge: Christian's and his own. Cyrano charges into battle. When he hears a Spaniard ask, 'Who are these men who are so eager for death. he begins to sing the song of the Cadets of Gascoyne. Cyrano charges off into a hail of bullets, singing as he fights.

0.text: The scene opens in Caesar's house. It is a stormy night and Calphurnia has dreamed of Caesar's murder. She asks a servant to instruct an augurer to interpret the signs, and she implores Caesar on her knees to stay at home. The servant returns, advising that Caesar should stay at home, and eventually he agrees, and he will advise Antony to tell the Senators that he is sick. Decius Brutus enters and he gives his interpretation to the omen. The vision concerned Romans dipping their hands in the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. Decius says that Calphurnia's dream represents Caesar's blood reviving Rome and the Romans are smiling because they are renewed. Decius goes on to suggest that the Senate will ridicule Caesar for being governed by his wife's dreams. Caesar changes his mind and goes to the Capitol. Caesar arrives and he welcomes Antony who is suffering the effects of partying the previous night.

2.text: In Caesar's home, the drama unfolded. The night was shrouded in turmoil, Calpurnia had a premonition that Caesar would be assassinated. She ordered her servants to summon the soothsayer to interpret the omen, and she knelt down to beg Caesar not to leave the house. The servants returned, saying that Caesar should stay indoors, and Caesar finally agreed, planning to let Antony tell the senators that he was ill. The twelfth Brutus entered, explaining the omen. The omen was about the Romans dipping their hands into the blood flowing from Caesar's statue. The twelfth Brutus said Calpurnia's dream was about Caesar's blood reviving Rome, and the Romans laughing at the revival. The twelfth Brutus continued, saying that the senators would mock Caesar being controlled by his wife's dream. Caesar changed his mind, deciding to go to the Senate. Caesar arrived, greeting Antony, who felt unwell due to the previous night's revelry.

He believes that the worst is over and doubts that another relapse could occur; if one did, it would most likely result from an intense experience that revived those same memories. Mr. Lorry also questions the wisdom of keeping the shoemaking bench and materials, pointing out that their presence reminds the Doctor of the past that has caused him so much pain. Dr. Alexander explained that he believed these things would happen again because some events had left a deep impression on his memory. He thought the worst was over, but he suspected they might happen again; if that was the case, those intense experiences might trigger the same memories.

Mr. Laurie also pointed out that leaving the sewing table and tools meant their existence would remind Dr. Alexander of his past suffering. Dr. Alexander anxiously agreed and asked Mr. Laurie and Mrs. Pross if they had done anything to Lucy and Denis before he left.

Therefore, after Dr. Alexander left, Mr. Laurie and Mrs. Pross buried the tools and burned the sewing table.

0.text: The Underground Man wishes that his constant state of inaction were simply because of laziness. That sure would make things easier. And at least then, he says, he could respect himself. Also, at least he would have certainty. If someone asked what he was, the answer would be clear: a lazy person! For example: the Underground Man once knew a guy who was a connoisseur of Lafitte . That was pretty much the guy's only defining feature, but at least he had a defining feature. So he died a happy man. The point is that the Underground Man has no such vocation. If he could pick something to be, he'd pick...mmm...a glutton . A glutton who can appreciate 'everything sublime and beautiful.' The more he thinks about it, the more he realizes that should have been what his life was about: appreciating the sublime and beautiful. He realizes that such a life would probably have meant a lot of crying. Any time someone did anything beautiful or sublime, he would have wept in awe. He also would have gotten fat and red in the nose.

0.text: Coriolanus shows up at the marketplace ready to deliver the big apology. The plebeians, along with Sicinius and Brutus, are waiting for him. First, Menenius reminds everyone that Coriolanus is a big war hero with the scars to prove it. The tribunes decide it's time to pounce and waste no time provoking Coriolanus. Sicinius officially accuses him of acting like a big old tyrant and a traitor, which--big shock--sends Coriolanus into yet another rage. Coriolanus proceeds to insult the tribunes and plebeians, daring them to punish him with exile, death, or torture. Meanwhile, his senator buddies can only stand by and watch this train wreck unfold. Finally, the tribunes declare that Coriolanus is banned from Rome 4EVA. Coriolanus is all 'Oh yeah? I don't think so. You're not banishing me. I'm banishing you!'

2.text: Cornelius appeared on the market, preparing to loudly apologize. Ordinary citizens, including Cicero and Brutus, were waiting for him. First, Menenius reminded everyone that Cornelius was a great hero, and the scars were evidence. The officials decided that it was now the time to launch an attack, not to waste time entangling themselves with Cornelius. Cicero formally accused him of behaving like an old tyrant, and like a traitor, which again plunged Cornelius into anger. Cornelius continued to insult the officials and ordinary citizens, daring to exile, kill, or torture them. Meanwhile, his senatorial friends could only stand by and watch the accident unfold. Finally, the officials announced that Cornelius would never be allowed to leave Rome again. Cornelius said, 'Oh, really? I don't think so. You can't exile me. I'm the one who will exile you!'

0.text: The Wood-Sawyer Lucie is unsure for one year and three months whether her husband has been alive or dead. She establishes a routine in their new home, and she keeps herself hopeful by setting aside a chair or books for her husband and otherwise behaving as if he lived there, too. Her father informs her that there is a place that she can stand on the sidewalk during certain hours which is overlooked by a window in the prison which her husband may sometimes look out. Lucie faithfully walks back and forth on that sidewalk for two hours each day. Jacques Four has now become a wood-sawyer and has a shack to cut wood near where Lucie walks. He notices that she is there every day, and he mocks her for knowing someone in the prison, pretending to guillotine the whole family with his saw. During December, a crowd of five hundred including Jacques Four and the Vengeance descend on Lucie while she is walking near the prison. She is frightened, but her father reassures her that they will not harm her. Madame Defarge walks by and salutes them. Charles is summoned to appear in court the next day

2.text:
Lucy's husband is already dead, at least Lucy thinks so, she wandered aimlessly on the road for three years. Lucy established a daily routine in their new home, reserving a chair or some books so that her husband could be with her. Her father told her that Lucy could stand on the sidewalk, she could see a window of the prison, her husband might look out from there sometimes. Lucy persisted in walking on that sidewalk for two hours every day without interruption. 

Jacques Four had become a carpenter, he noticed Lucy walking past his workshop every day and mocked her, saying she knew the prisoners, even mimicking their actions with his saw, pretending to chop down the entire family. 

In December, over 500 people, including Jacques Four and the Vengeance, surrounded Lucy, startling her, but her father reassured her that they wouldn't harm her. The Vengeance approached them, bowing to them. Charles was summoned to court.

Her father told her that Lucie stood on the sidewalk, she could see the windows of the prison, her husband might sometimes look out from there. Lucie insisted on walking on that sidewalk every day, without interruption for two hours.

Jean-Jacques Rousseau has become a carpenter, he noticed that Lucie walked past his workshop every day and mocked her, saying she knew those prisoners, even mimicking their movements, using his saw, pretending to cut down the entire family with it.

In December, over 500 people, including Jean-Jacques Rousseau and the avengers, surrounded Lucie, scaring her, but her father reassured her that they wouldn't harm her. The avengers approached them, bowing. Charles was summoned to court.

0.text: In the year 1640, the Hall of the Hotel de Bourgogne--a large, crowded Parisian theater--buzzes with activity in the minutes before a performance of the play La Clorise. People mill about and converse, divided according to their social class. A citizen guides his son through the room, impressing upon him the intellectual magnitude of the performance. A thief moves through the crowd, stealing handkerchiefs and purses. A group of pages runs about firing peashooters at one another. Two elegant marquises, with swords strapped to their waists, tread through the crowd, aloof and condescending. The lamps are lit, and the crowd cheers, knowing the performance will commence soon

2.text: In the grand hall of the Hotel de Bourgogne theatre in Paris in 1640, the air was electric with anticipation as the performance was about to begin. The audience milled about, chatting and gathering into different social groups. A citizen walked through the room with his son, explaining the intellectual value of the performance. Meanwhile, a pickpocket mingled with the crowd, snatching handkerchiefs and wallets. Servants darted through the crowd, playing a game of water pistol tag. Two noblemen, Marshal, walked through the crowd, hand on sword hilt, with cold, haughty gazes. The lights flashed, and the audience knew the show was about to start, so they began to get excited.

0.text: The setting shifts to the outside battlements of the castle at Elsinore. As earlier planned, Hamlet arrives with Horatio and Marcellus, just before midnight in order to watch for the Ghost. While they are speaking to one another, a flourish of trumpets and canon fire is heard in the distance. Hamlet explains in disgust that this is a sign that the new King, his uncle and stepfather, is engaged in his customary drunken revelry. Suddenly the ghost appears. Hamlet addresses the apparition as 'King, father; royal Dane' and implores it to reveal the reason for its nocturnal wanderings. The ghost simply beckons Hamlet to follow it to another place. Horatio and Marcellus beg Hamlet not to obey the ghost, fearing it would be dangerous and could even lead to his death; but Hamlet ignores his friends' warnings, breaks away from them when they try to physically restrain him, and follows the Ghost. Horatio and Marcellus are convinced that 'something is rotten in the state of Denmark' and decide to follow Hamlet.

2.text: On the outer walls of Elsinore Castle, the scene shifts. As previously mentioned, Hamlet arrives with Horatio and Marcellus shortly before midnight, preparing to observe the ghost. During their conversation, the distant sound of trumpets and cannons echoes through the air. Hamlet explains in a tone of disgust that this is a typical sign of the new king - his uncle and stepfather - holding a banquet. Suddenly, the ghost appears. Hamlet calls out, 'King, father, prince of Denmark,' begging it to reveal the reason for its nocturnal wanderings. The ghost merely waves its finger, indicating for Hamlet to follow it to another place. Horatio and Marcellus implore Hamlet not to follow the ghost's command, fearing it may lead him into danger, even possible death; but Hamlet ignores his friends' warnings, dispels their concerns, and follows the ghost. Horatio and Marcellus firmly believe 'the state of Denmark is not well,' and decide to follow Hamlet.

0.text: Diomedes sends his servant with a message to Cressida about how he just beat down her ex-boyfriend. He also sends along Troilus's horse as proof that he's now Cressida's 'knight' in shining armor. Agamemnon appears and lists all the Greeks who have been killed, including Achilles' lover, Patroclus. He and Diomedes run off to get reinforcements while Nestor shows up to deliver the bad news about Patroclus. Then he tells us that Hector is running around the battlefield mowing down Greek warriors like a one-man army. Ulysses runs up and says that Achilles is 'weeping, cursing' and 'vowing vengeance' for Patroclus' death. We find out that Achilles and his gang of hooligan 'Myrmidons' are out for Hector's blood. Ajax runs in looking to kill Troilus.

2.text: Diomedes sent a servant with a letter to Chryseis, informing her that he had just defeated her former boyfriend. He also brought Hector's horse as evidence to prove that he was now Chryseis' 'noble knight.' Agamemnon appeared, listing a long list of Greek warriors who had fallen, including Patroclus, Achilles' lover. He and Diomedes rushed to the front lines seeking reinforcements, while Nestor appeared with bad news about Patroclus' death. He then told us that Hector was madly slaughtering Greek warriors on the battlefield like a unique legion. 0.text: The witches again meet at an open place, this time with Hecate, the goddess of witches, who looks pretty angry. Hecate lays into the weird sisters in a lengthy, rhyming speech that sounds a bit like a nursery rhyme. She's super irritated that they were meddling in the affairs of Macbeth without consulting her first, as she could've done a better job. Also, she points out, Macbeth isn't devoted to them, only to himself. But, fine, Hecate will clean up this mess. She tells them to all meet in the morning, when Macbeth will come to know his destiny, whatever that means. Then there's a catchy witch song and dance, and everyone exits after Hecate. FYI: Some literary critics believe that these scene is way too hokey to be Shakespeare's work, so it must have been added to the play some time between the time the play was first written and its publication in the first folio , which was after Shakespeare's death . A fellow playwright, Thomas Middleton, may have written the snazzy songs in this scene.

2.text:

Hecate also pointed out that Macbeth was not loyal to them, but to himself. However, Hecate decided to intervene in the situation. Hecate ordered them to gather again the next morning, and Macbeth would then know his fate. After that, the witches' song and dance appeared, and everyone left Hecate's side.

Some literary critics believe that this scene is too childish and should not be part of the original Shakespearean work, thus speculating that it may have been added to the first edition of the play after Shakespeare's death. Another playwright of Shakespeare's time, Thomas Middleton, may have written the captivating songs in this scene.

0.text: Lydgate was indifferent to the voting on the question of chaplaincy at the hospital. Having met Farebrother and been drawn to him, he faces a dilemma. His personal preference is for Farebrother, who has a humane touch and who has been serving as chaplain all along without pay. Now that the post is an earned one, it seems unfair to deprive him. On the other hand, Bulstrode is Lydgates main backer in the town, where he anticipates serious oppositions to his plans for medical reform. Lydgate, therefore, attends the meeting in a confused state. There is heated discussion much of personal, among the members who have earlier assembled. Lydgate comes in last and finds them equally divided. Ultimately, his casting vote is decided by his smarting ego. Mr. Wrench, an old style medical practitioner, declares that it is well known that Lydgate will vote will Bulstrode. Incensed, Lydgate does just that. So Mr. Tyke becomes the hospital chaplain. 0.text: Book II, Chapter 6 Carrie accompanies the Gormers to one of their new houses and while there meets George Dorset while taking a walk. He pleads with her to give him some proof of his wife's infidelities, implying that he wants to divorce her and marry Lily instead. Lily becomes afraid and runs away from him, telling him she cannot help. When she returns to the Gormer house, Mrs. Gormer informs her that Bertha Dorset had been there for a visit. Lily head back to the city and finds a place in a hotel, paying more for her rent than she can afford. She is soon visited by Mr. Dorset who implores her to help him out of his situation, but Lily refuses to reveal anything. She then goes to visit Carrie Fisher and finds Rosedale in Carrie's house, most likely invited there so he and Lily could meet. After the dinner Carrie talks with Lily alone, and tells her that in order to defeat Bertha Dorset, Lily will have to either marry Mr. Dorset or marry someone else.

0.text: Babbitt is elected as an official delegate to the annual convention for the State Association of Real Estate Boards. When Cecil Rountree, the chairman of the convention program-committee, asks Babbitt to write a paper espousing his views about real estate for the convention, Babbitt eagerly accepts the honor. However, he encounters trouble in writing the paper because he becomes mired in concerns about 'Style, Order, and other mysteries. ' Finally, he dispenses with all of these concerns and produces a concise, clear presentation on his thoughts about the real estate business. Babbitt reads his paper before the convention and is instantly hailed as the equal of Cecil Rountree, who is known as a 'diplomat of business.' Babbitt revels in his newfound respect and decides not to return home right away. He remains behind to drink, smoke, attend a burlesque show, and visit a brothel with some of the other delegates. Afterwards, Babbitt never tells anyone about that evening. When he returns to Zenith, it is business as usual.

Babit gained new dignity at the conference and decided not to return home immediately. He stayed in the conference hall, drinking and smoking with other delegates, watching comedies, and even visiting a brothel.

0.text: The Lilliputian emperor is pleased that Gulliver is friendly and cooperative, so he rewards him with some court diversions. The diversions, however, prove to be quite different than one might expect. It is the Lilliputian court custom that men seeking political office demonstrate their agility in rope dancing, among other things. How long and how skillfully a candidate can dance upon a rope determines his tenure in office. Of the candidates, two are particularly adept: Reldresal, Gulliver's friend, and Flimnap, the treasurer. Other diversions include noblemen competing for official favor by crawling under or leaping over a stick, a feat for which they are then rewarded with various colored threads. Gulliver also reviews the Emperor's troops; he stands, legs apart, while the tiny men march through. As a result of Gulliver's cooperation, a pact between Gulliver and the Emperor is agreed on. Gulliver is granted limited freedom on certain conditions. In return for abiding by the conditions, he will receive food sufficient for 1,728 Lilliputians. Gulliver swears to the articles in proper form, and the Emperor frees him.

2.text: Lippoldwood Emperor was very pleased with Gilderoy's friendly cooperation and gifted him some court entertainment. However, these entertainment activities were far from what people might expect. In the Lippoldwood Court tradition, candidates running for political positions must demonstrate their agility through activities such as the rope dance. The skill of rope dance and the length of time the candidate can sustain it determine their position in office. Among the candidates, Redressal and Flinnapp (Lippoldwood Emperor's Chancellor of the Exchequer) are particularly skilled in the rope dance. Other entertainment activities include nobles crawling or jumping over wooden beams to win the emperor's favor, with successful ones receiving various colored ropes. Gilderoy also visited the emperor's army, standing with his legs apart, and mini-soldiers passing through his legs. Due to Gilderoy's cooperation, an agreement was reached between Gilderoy and the emperor. Gilderoy gained limited freedom but under conditions. Gilderoy adhered to these conditions, sufficient to feed 1,728 Lippoldwood people. Gilderoy swore formally to uphold these terms, and the emperor released him.

The skill of the rope dance and the time the candidates could maintain it determined their status in the position. Among the candidates, Redressal and Flinnap (the Emperor's financial officer) were particularly skilled in the rope dance. Other entertainment activities included nobles crawling or jumping over wooden planks to win the favor of the Emperor, and the winner would receive a colored rope. Gilderoy also visited the Emperor's army, standing with his legs apart, with miniature soldiers passing through his legs. Due to Gilderoy's cooperation, Gilderoy and the Emperor reached an agreement. Gilderoy gained a certain degree of freedom, but was subject to certain conditions. Gilderoy adhered to these conditions, which were enough to sustain 1728 Lipwood people. Gilderoy formally swore to abide by these terms, and the Emperor released him.

0.text: The Mail On a Friday night in late November of 1775, a mail coach wends its way from London to Dover. The journey proves so treacherous that the three passengers must dismount from the carriage and hike alongside it as it climbs a steep hill. From out of the great mists, a messenger on horseback appears and asks to speak to Jarvis Lorry of Tellson's Bank. The travelers react warily, fearing that they have come upon a highwayman or robber. Mr. Lorry, however, recognizes the messenger's voice as that of Jerry Cruncher, the odd-job man at Tellson's, and accepts his message. The note that Jerry passes him reads: 'Wait at Dover for Mam'selle. Lorry instructs Jerry to return to Tellson's with this reply: 'Recalled to Life. Confused and troubled by the 'blazing strange message,' Jerry rides on to deliver it

2.text: On a Friday afternoon in late November 1875, a slow-moving carriage was making its way from London to Dover. This journey was unusually perilous, and three passengers were forced to disembark and walk alongside the carriage as it navigated a steep slope through thick fog. Suddenly, a mounted orderly emerged from the mist, demanding to see Mr. Jarvis Lorry of Tidings Bank. The passengers eyed him warily, fearing they might be encountering a highwayman or a bandit. 0.text: Spring arrives, and Gray Beaver finishes the journey. White Fang is one year old, and next to Lip-lip, he is the largest yearling. He continues to have his battles with other dogs. When he fights with Baseek over a piece of shinbone, White Fang rips Baseeks right ear and wounds him on the shoulder. Baseek, old and weak, gives up. In mid-summer, White Fang encounters Kiche, who has now forgotten him and has had a new litter. She hovers protectively around her litter, trying to drive White Fang away. When White Fang is three years old, there is a great famine in the land. Only the strong will survive, for the Indians eat the weaker dogs. The Indians also eat the soft-tanned leather of their moccasins and mittens to fill their stomachs. White Fang escapes into the forest to hunt on his own, at times robbing rabbit snares and at times capturing small game, like squirrels and woodmice. At the end of the famine, White Fang meets Lip-lip, with whom he fights until Lip-lip is killed. He then returns to the village and is received warmly and given plenty of fish.

In the spring, a shaggy old dog and a white wolf dog completed a long journey together. There was also a young dog named Ripley, the largest of all the dogs. The shaggy old dog often fought with other dogs. One day, he fought with a fat cat over a bone, and the white wolf dog grabbed the fat cat's ear, hurting him. After being injured, the fat cat finally gave up.

In mid-summer, the white wolf dog met Chick, but she had already forgotten him and gave birth to puppies. She protected her puppies and tried to chase the white wolf dog away. The white wolf dog was three years old when a severe famine broke out. Only the strongest dogs could survive, and the Indians ate the weaker dogs. They even ate the soft leather of their boots and gloves.

The white wolf dog hunted alone in the forest, sometimes stealing rabbit traps, sometimes catching small animals like squirrels and rodents. After the famine ended, the white wolf dog met Ripley again, and after a fierce battle, he returned to the village, where the villagers warmly welcomed him and gave him a large amount of fish as a gift.

0.text: It is a cold, wet November afternoon when the novel opens at Gateshead, the home of Jane Eyre's relatives, the Reeds. Jane and the Reed children, Eliza, John, and Georgiana sit in the drawing room. Jane's aunt is angry with her, purposely excluding her from the rest of the family, so Jane sits alone in a window seat, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly reads, her cousin John torments her, reminding her of her precarious position within the household. As orphaned niece of Mrs. Reed, she should not be allowed to live with gentlemen's children. John throws a book at Jane and she calls him a 'murderer' and 'slave-driver.' The two children fight, and Jane is blamed for the quarrel. As punishment, she is banished to the red-room.

So Jane sat alone in a chair by the window, reading Bewick's History of British Birds. As she quietly read, her cousin John teased her, reminding her of her vulnerable position in the family. As the illegitimate daughter of late Mrs. Reed, she shouldn't be allowed to live with the gentleman children. John threw a book at Jane, calling her a 'murderer' and a 'slave owner.' The two children fought, and Jane was blamed for causing the trouble. As punishment, she was sent to the red room.

0.text: Cedric is in his home, Rotherwood, impatiently waiting for his servants to come home. He is also displeased that his ward Rowena is late for supper. His thoughts are interrupted by the blast of a horn. Then the gatekeeper announces that Prior Aymer of the Abbey of Jorvaulx, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and a small party of men are on their way to the royal tournament at Ashby-de-la-Zouche and want to lodge at Rotherwood for the night. Cedric does not want to entertain these Normans, but his Saxon pride demands that they be offered hospitality; however, he clings to his dignity by refusing to go out to welcome them. Only when they come to him in his hall does Cedric reluctantly welcome them. Cedric counsels Rowena against appearing before the guests. He does not trust the Knight Templar and does not want anything to interfere with his plans to marry Rowena off to the right gentleman. She, however, is keen to hear the latest news from the Holy Land from the Palmer, since she is in love with Ivanhoe, whom she thinks is still fighting in the Crusades.

2.text: Cedric anxiously waited in the Rotherwood estate for his servants to return home. He was also displeased that his guardian, Rowena, had missed dinner. His thoughts were interrupted by the loud blast of a horn. The steward then announced the arrival of the elder Emmer, Brian de Bois-Guilbert and a small group from the monastery of Jorvax, who were passing through the Royal Arena and stopping for the night in Ashby-de-la-Zouch. Cedric was unwilling to provide hospitality to these Normans, but his Saxon pride demanded that he show them respect; however, he insisted on maintaining his dignity and refused to receive them personally. It was not until they entered the hall that Cedric begrudgingly received them. He advised Rowena not to appear before the guests. He was wary of the knights of the Order and did not want anything to disrupt his plan to marry Rowena off to a suitable gentleman. However, he longed to hear the latest news from the Holy Land from the wandering monk, for she had fallen in love with Ivanhoe, whom she believed was still on the Crusade.

4.text: Sedric anxiously awaited his servant's return at Rotherwood Manor, and he was also displeased that his guardian, Rowan, had missed dinner. His thoughts were interrupted by the loud sound of a trumpet. 0.text: Five Years Later It is now 1780. Tellson's Bank in London prides itself on being 'very small, very dark, very ugly, very incommodious. Were it more welcoming, the bank's partners believe, it would lose its status as a respectable business. It is located by Temple Bar, the spot where, until recently, the government displayed the heads of executed criminals. The narrator explains that at this time, 'death was a recipe much in vogue,' used against all manner of criminals, from forgers to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher, employed by Tellson's as a runner and messenger, wakes up in his small apartment, located in an unsavory London neighborhood. He begins the day by yelling at his wife for 'praying against' him; he throws his muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son camp outside Tellson's Bank, where they await the bankers' instructions. When an indoor messenger calls for a porter, Cruncher takes off to do the job. As young Jerry sits alone, he wonders why his father's fingers always have rust on them

2.text:
Five years later

It was now the year 1780. Tellson's Bank in London proudly declared itself to be 'very small, very black, very ugly, very uncomfortable.' If it were more inviting, the partners believed it would lose its respectable status. It was situated beside St. Barts Church on the Thames, where the government had recently displayed the heads of executed prisoners. The narrator explained that at that time, 'death was in fashion,' used to deal with all sorts of offenders, from counterfeiters to horse thieves to counterfeiters. Jerry Cruncher was Tellson's Bank messenger and runner, who woke up in a small apartment on a dirty street in London. He began his work, cursing his wife to 'beg' him; he threw a muddy boot at her. Around nine o'clock, Cruncher and his young son were camping outside Tellson's Bank, waiting for the instructions of the bankers. When an indoor runner woke up the doorman, Cruncher went to do this. The young Jerry felt lonely, wondering why his father's fingers were always rusty.

0.text: Mr. Lorry arrives at the Royal George Hotel in Dover and after refreshing himself, spends the day pondering on his mission while he waits for the young woman who is Lucie Manette. She arrives believing that there is some property belonging to her late father in Paris, but Mr. Lorry breaks the news to her that her father is still alive. He is Dr. Manette who has been imprisoned in the Bastille in Paris for the last eighteen years. The French authorities have recently released him and as he was one of Tellson's Bank's clients, Mr. Lorry has been sent to identify him. It is hoped that Lucie will take the responsibility for caring for her father and bringing him back to health. Lucie is taken aback at this news and she faints. A large red-haired woman runs into the room pushing Mr. Lorry aside and going to the young lady's assistance using smelling salts and cold water to revive her.

0.text: The Prison Door This first chapter contains little in the way of action, instead setting the scene and introducing the first of many symbols that will come to dominate the story. A crowd of somber, dreary-looking people has gathered outside the door of a prison in seventeenth-century Boston. The building's heavy oak door is studded with iron spikes, and the prison appears to have been constructed to hold dangerous criminals. No matter how optimistic the founders of new colonies may be, the narrator tells us, they invariably provide for a prison and a cemetery almost immediately. This is true of the citizens of Boston, who built their prison some twenty years earlier. The one incongruity in the otherwise drab scene is the rosebush that grows next to the prison door. The narrator suggests that it offers a reminder of Nature's kindness to the condemned; for his tale, he says, it will provide either a 'sweet moral blossom' or else some relief in the face of unrelenting sorrow and gloom

0.text: Tom Foster moved to Winesburg with his grandmother as a teenager. She cleans Banker White's house. Tom used to be the stable boy at the Whites' house, but because he is rather dreamy and irresponsible, he lost that position. Now, he does odd jobs and is quite happy. His grandmother comes regularly to clean his rented rooms, and he has a rather oddly disciplined approach to life experiences. He wants to do things, but he chooses specific experiences and then goes out and intentionally lives them. For example, having fallen in love with Helen White, he limits what he allows himself to think about her. One night, he decides he ought to try drinking to see what it feels like. He buys a bottle of whiskey and walks about a mile north of town, where he sits on a bank of grass and gets drunk. In his drunkenness, he goes and talks to George Willard about Helen. George is upset at first, but then they cement a bond between them. Tom decides that, now that he has been drunk, he will not need to try it again.

Thomas Foster moved to Winesburg with his grandmother when he was young. His grandmother had been the servant of Mr. White. Thomas was once Mr. White's coachman, but he lost his job because he was too impulsive and irresponsible. Now, he makes a living by doing odd jobs and is very happy. His grandmother often cleans the room he rents, and he has a rather peculiar attitude towards life. He longs for experiences, but he chooses specific experiences and deliberately goes through them. 

For instance, as soon as he laid eyes on Helen White, he fell in love with her, but he restricted his thoughts about her. One night, he decided to try out what it felt like to get drunk. He bought a bottle of whiskey and walked a mile or so north of town, sat on the grass and got drunk. After getting drunk, he went to look for George Willard and Helen to talk to. George was initially very displeased, but later a strong friendship developed between them. Thomas decided that since he had already tried drinking, he didn't need to try it again.

0.text: Incidents In Philadelphia When the boat reached Philadelphia, Harriet earnestly thanked the captain for his kindness. He introduced her to the Rev. Jeremiah Durham, who said that Harriet could stay with him for a few days before she was able to get to New York. Fanny was placed with another family. Mrs. Durham was an extremely pleasant and solicitous woman and made Harriet feel very welcome. Harriet was awed by the bustle and diversity of Philadelphia. It was very different from her home in the south; that evening when the bells signaling a fire were heard, Harriet assumed the whole town had to get up and respond. She considered herself 'an ignorant child, just beginning to learn how things went on in great cities. After five days one of Mrs. Durham's friends decided to accompany Harriet and Fanny to New York. In their travels Harriet observed that the North was in some ways no better than the south, for colored people were treated quite differently

2.text:
The Philadelphia Event

When the ship arrived in Philadelphia, Harriet sincerely thanked the captain for his kindness. The captain introduced her to Reverend Jeremiah Doremus, who told her she could stay with him in Philadelphia for a few days until she could get to New York. Fanny was arranged to stay with another family. Mrs. Doremus was a very pleasant and caring woman, who made Harriet feel very welcome. Harriet was amazed at the grandeur and diversity of Philadelphia, which was a world apart from her home in the South; that night, when she heard the alarm bells, Harriet thought the whole city was at war. She felt like 'a foolish child, just starting to learn the workings of the city.' Five days later, Mrs. Doremus's friend decided to accompany Harriet and Fanny to New York. During their journey, Harriet noticed that the North was not any better than the South in some ways, as the treatment of people of color was completely different.
